instruction:
Create a comprehensive language learning curriculum for French, targeting beginner level students with no prior knowledge of the language. Structure the curriculum using a YAML format that divides the content over a 12-week period. Each week should contain specific learning objectives, key vocabulary, grammatical concepts, pronunciation practice, cultural notes, recommended readings, and multimedia resources to aid learning. 

YAML format specifications:
- Use proper indentation and avoid the use of tabs.
- Each week should be presented as a dictionary with nested items for each section. 
- Learning objectives, vocabulary, and grammatical concepts are required sections and must be in the form of a list.
- Pronunciation practice should include instructions and examples.
- Cultural notes should provide brief insights into French customs or traditions relevant to the week's content.
- Recommended readings and multimedia resources (links) must be included where suitable, with titles and brief descriptions.

Make sure to include the following for each week:
1. `week`: week number (1-12)
2. `learning_objectives`: at least three goals for the week
3. `vocabulary`: at least 20 new French words with their English translation
4. `grammar`: introduce one primary grammatical concept and provide example sentences
5. `pronunciation`: focus on one or two specific sounds, with instructions on how to produce them and example words
6. `cultural_notes`: at least one note for exposing students to French culture
7. `readings`: at least one recommended reading (fiction or non-fiction) relevant to the week's content
8. `multimedia_resources`: include at least two types of resources (videos, podcasts, etc.)

Example of YAML content for Week 1 (Please create unique content for Weeks 2 - 12):

```yaml
week_01:
  learning_objectives:
    - Introduce yourself in French
    - Understand basic French greetings
    - Recognize numbers 1-10 in French
  vocabulary:
    - Bonjour: Hello
    - Au revoir: Goodbye
    - Merci: Thank you
    - ...
  grammar:
    - Concept: Definite and indefinite articles (le, la, les, un, une, des)
      Examples:
        - Le garçon: The boy
        - Une fille: A girl
        - Des pommes: Some apples
  pronunciation:
    - Focus: The French 'r' sound
      Instructions: Produced in the throat, similar to gargling water.
      Examples:
        - Rouge: Red
        - Frère: Brother
  cultural_notes:
    - The importance of saying "Bonjour" when entering shops in France.
  readings:
    - Title: "First French Reader: A Beginner's Dual-Language Book"
      Description: A collection of French short stories for beginners with parallel English translations.
  multimedia_resources:
    - Type: Video
      Title: "Basic French Greetings"
      Link: http://example.com/french-greetings
    - Type: Podcast
      Title: "Numbers in French"
      Link: http://example.com/french-numbers-podcast
```

If necessary, you may invent suitable titles, contents, and links for readings and multimedia resources for Weeks 2-12, adhering to the overall structure and format specifications provided above.
output:
```yaml
week_02:
  learning_objectives:
    - Ask and respond to basic questions about personal information (name, age, nationality, etc.)
    - Use basic French verbs (être, avoir, aller) in the present tense
    - Recognize and use basic French prepositions (à, de, en) correctly
  vocabulary:
    - Comment ça va?: How are you?
    - Je m'appelle: My name is
    - J'ai: I have
    - ...
  grammar:
    - Concept: Present tense of être, avoir, and aller
      Examples:
        - Je suis: I am
        - Tu as: You have
        - Nous allons: We go
  pronunciation:
    - Focus: The difference between "u" and "ou" sounds
      Instructions: The "u" sound is produced by puckering the lips, while the "ou" sound is produced by rounding the lips.
      Examples:
        - Une rue: A street (u sound)
        - Une roue: A wheel (ou sound)
  cultural_notes:
    - The importance of French cuisine and the role of food in French culture.
  readings:
    - Title: "French for Beginners: The Ultimate Guide to Kickstart Your Learning"
      Description: A comprehensive guide to learning French for beginners.
  multimedia_resources:
    - Type: Video
      Title: "Basic French Verbs"
      Link: http://example.com/french-verbs
    - Type: Podcast
      Title: "French Prepositions"
      Link: http://example.com/french-prepositions-podcast

week_03:
  learning_objectives:
    - Describe people, places, and things using adjectives
    - Use possessive adjectives (mon, ma, mes) correctly
    - Ask and respond to questions about likes and dislikes
  vocabulary:
    - Grand: Tall
    - Petite: Small
    - Mon livre: My book
    - ...
  grammar:
    - Concept: Adjectives and possessive adjectives
      Examples:
        - Un chat noir: A black cat
        - Ma voiture rouge: My red car
        - Mes amis français: My French friends
  pronunciation:
    - Focus: The difference between "é" and "è" sounds
      Instructions: The "é" sound is produced by opening the mouth and raising the tongue towards the top of the mouth, while the "è" sound is produced by opening the mouth and lowering the tongue towards the bottom of the mouth.
      Examples:
        - Café: Coffee (é sound)
        - Père: Father (è sound)
  cultural_notes:
    - The importance of fashion in French culture and the role of Paris as a fashion capital.
  readings:
    - Title: "Le Petit Prince" by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
      Description: A classic French novella about a young prince who travels to different planets.
  multimedia_resources:
    - Type: Video
      Title: "French Adjectives"
      Link: http://example.com/french-adjectives
    - Type: Podcast
      Title: "Likes and Dislikes in French"
      Link: http://example.com/french-likes-dislikes-podcast

week_04:
  learning_objectives:
    - Express time and daily routines in French
    - Use reflexive verbs (se laver, se réveiller, etc.) correctly
    - Use the verb "faire" to describe daily activities
  vocabulary:
    - Le matin: Morning
    - Se brosser les dents: To brush one's teeth
    - Faire du sport: To do sports
    - ...
  grammar:
    - Concept: Reflexive verbs and the verb "faire"
      Examples:
        - Je me lave: I wash myself
        - Tu te réveilles: You wake up
        - Nous faisons du vélo: We ride bikes
  pronunciation:
    - Focus: The difference between "in" and "an" nasal sounds
      Instructions: The "in" sound is produced by closing the mouth and producing sound through the nose, while the "an" sound is produced by opening the mouth and producing sound through the nose.
      Examples:
        - Vin: Wine (in sound)
        - Blanc: White (an sound)
  cultural_notes:
    - The importance of the French language in international diplomacy and the role of the francophonie.
  readings:
    - Title: "French Short Stories for Beginners" by Olly Richards
      Description: A collection of short stories in French with English translations for beginner learners.
  multimedia_resources:
    - Type: Video
      Title: "Daily Routines in French"
      Link: http://example.com/french-daily-routines
    - Type: Podcast
      Title: "Reflexive Verbs in French"
      Link: http://example.com/french-reflexive-verbs-podcast

week_05:
  learning_objectives:
    - Use the past tense (passé composé) to describe past events
    - Use irregular past participles (avoir and être) correctly
    - Use time expressions (hier, la semaine dernière, etc.) to describe past events
  vocabulary:
    - Hier: Yesterday
    - La semaine dernière: Last week
    - Fait: Done (past participle of faire)
    - ...
  grammar:
    - Concept: Past tense (passé composé) and irregular past participles
      Examples:
        - J'ai mangé: I ate
        - Tu es allé: You went
        - Nous avons vu: We saw
  pronunciation:
    - Focus: The nasal "on" sound
      Instructions: The "on" sound is produced by closing the mouth and producing sound through the nose while pronouncing the "o" sound.
      Examples:
        - Bon: Good
        - Long: Long
  cultural_notes:
    - The importance of the French language in African countries and the role of French colonialism in Africa.
  readings:
    - Title: "French Short Stories 2 for Intermediate Learners" by Frederic Bibard
      Description: A collection of French short stories for intermediate learners.
  multimedia_resources:
    - Type: Video
      Title: "Passé Composé in French"
      Link: http://example.com/french-passe-compose
    - Type: Podcast
      Title: "Irregular Past Participles in French"
      Link: http://example.com/french-irregular-past-participles-podcast

week_06:
  learning_objectives:
    - Use the future tense (futur simple) to describe future events
    - Use regular and irregular verbs correctly in the future tense
    - Use time expressions (demain, la semaine prochaine, etc.) to describe future events
  vocabulary:
    - Demain: Tomorrow
    - La semaine prochaine: Next week
    - Sera: Will be (future tense of être)
    - ...
  grammar:
    - Concept: Future tense (futur simple) and irregular verbs
      Examples:
        - J'irai: I will go
        - Tu auras: You will have
        - Nous serons: We will be
  pronunciation:
    - Focus: The "eu" and "u" sounds
      Instructions: The "eu" sound is produced by rounding the lips and producing sound through the nose, while the "u" sound is produced by puckering the lips and producing sound through the nose.
      Examples:
        - Peur: Fear (eu sound)
        - Rue: Street (u sound)
  cultural_notes:
    - The importance of French literature and the role of French writers in shaping global literature.
  readings:
    - Title: "Les Misérables" by Victor Hugo
      Description: A classic French novel about the struggles of the French working class.
  multimedia_resources:
    - Type: Video
      Title: "Future Tense in French"
      Link: http://example.com/french-future-tense
    - Type: Podcast
      Title: "Irregular Verbs in the Future Tense"
      Link: http://example.com/french-irregular-verbs-future-tense-podcast

week_07:
  learning_objectives:
    - Use the conditional tense (conditionnel présent) to describe hypothetical situations
    - Use the conditional mood (si clauses) to express hypothetical situations
    - Use irregular verbs correctly in the conditional tense
  vocabulary:
    - Si: If
    - S'il pleut: If it rains
    - Serait: Would be (conditional tense of être)
    - ...
  grammar:
    - Concept: Conditional tense (conditionnel présent) and si clauses
      Examples:
        - Je serais heureux si je gagnais: I would be happy if I won
        - Tu aurais faim si tu ne mangeais pas: You would be hungry if you didn't eat
        - Nous irions à la plage si le temps était beau: We would go to the beach if the weather was nice
  pronunciation:
    - Focus: The "an" and "en" nasal sounds
      Instructions: The "an" sound is produced by opening the mouth and producing sound through the nose, while the "en" sound is produced by closing the mouth and producing sound through the nose.
      Examples:
        - Grand: Tall (an sound)
        - Vent: Wind (en sound)
  cultural_notes:
    - The importance of French cinema and the role of French filmmakers in shaping global cinema.
  readings:
    - Title: "Le Tour du Monde en 80 Jours" by Jules Verne
      Description: A classic French novel about a man who travels around the world in 80 days.
  multimedia_resources:
    - Type: Video
      Title: "Conditional Tense in French"
      Link: http://example.com/french-conditional-tense
    - Type: Podcast
      Title: "Si Clauses in French"
      Link: http://example.com/french-si-clauses-podcast

week_08:
  learning_objectives:
    - Use the imperative (impératif) to give commands
    - Use regular and irregular verbs correctly in the imperative
    - Use reflexive verbs correctly in the imperative
  vocabulary:
    - Mange!: Eat! (imperative of manger)
    - Va-t'en!: Go away! (imperative of aller)
    - Lève-toi!: Get up! (imperative of se lever)

      Examples:

  pronunciation:
    - Focus: The "in" and "un" nasal sounds
      Instructions: The "in" sound is produced by closing the mouth and producing sound through the nose, while the "un" sound is produced by opening the mouth and producing sound through the nose.
      Examples:
        - Pain: Bread (in sound)

  cultural_notes:
    - The importance of French art and the role of French artists in shaping global art movements.
  readings:
    - Title: "Madame Bovary" by Gustave Flaubert
      Description: A classic French novel about a woman who tries to escape her unhappy marriage.
  multimedia_resources:

      Title: "Imperative in French"
      Link: http://example.com/french-imperative
    - Type: Podcast
      Title: "Reflexive Verbs in the Imperative"
      Link: http://example.com/french-reflexive-verbs-imperative-podcast

week_09:

    - Focus: The "euil" and "ueil" sounds
      Instructions: The "euil" sound is produced by rounding the lips and producing sound through the nose, while the "ueil" sound is produced by puckering the lips and producing sound through the nose.
      Examples:
        - Oeil: Eye (euil sound)
        - Soleil: Sun (ueil

instruction:
Create an advanced language learning module for Spanish targeted at English speakers who have an intermediate grasp of Spanish. The module should be structured as a week-long lesson plan focusing on the subjunctive mood, a complex grammatical concept. Each day's content must be formatted using 'Markdown' with the following specific configurations.

- **Day 1:** Introduction to the Subjunctive Mood
    - Use a `###` header for the day's topic.
    - Write a brief paragraph explaining the subjunctive mood in English.
    - Include a `> blockquote` with a common phrase that illustrates the use of the subjunctive mood.
    - Construct a table with two columns: "Indicative" vs "Subjunctive", contrasting example sentences in each mode.

- **Day 2:** When to Use the Subjunctive
    - Employ `####` headers for each situation that calls for the subjunctive.
    - Provide a bulleted list using `-` under each header with specific triggers for the subjunctive (e.g., doubt, emotion, impersonal expressions).
    - Insert an info box using `***` before and after for a tip on memorizing triggers.

- **Day 3:** Forming the Subjunctive
    - Utilize `####` headers for "Regular Verbs" and "Irregular Verbs".
    - Show conjugation tables for -ar, -er, and -ir verbs in the subjunctive mood, ensuring that each conjugation cell is formatted in **bold**.
    - Supply a separate code block formatted with triple backticks for irregular verb conjugations that deviate from the standard patterns.

- **Day 4:** Subjunctive in Noun Clauses
    - Introduce this use of the subjunctive with a `###` header.
    - List example sentences in a numbered list using `1.` for each new example.
    - Create a collapsible section using `<details><summary>Click to expand</summary>` that includes practice exercises with their translations in English.

- **Day 5:** Subjunctive in Adjective Clauses
    - Use a `###` header for the topic.
    - Describe adjective clauses with a subjunctive in a paragraph format.
    - Present example sentences with the subjunctive highlighted using `**text**`.
    - Embed an image (you may use a placeholder link, e.g., `![Placeholder Image](#)`) that visually represents the use of the subjunctive in adjective clauses.

- **Day 6:** Subjunctive in Adverbial Clauses
    - Begin with a `###` header.
    - Include a definition and explanation in paragraph form.
    - Elaborate on different conjunctions that require the subjunctive in adverbial clauses using a bulleted list `-`.
    - Offer an interactive element, such as a quiz, formatted with checkboxes `- [ ]` for each answer choice.

- **Day 7:** Putting It All Together
    - Commence with a `###` header.
    - Summarize the week's lessons in a concise list using `-`.
    - Construct a fictional dialogue between two characters using the subjunctive mood, formatted as a script, with character names in **bold** before each line.
    - Conclude with a series of practice scenarios where students must decide if the subjunctive is needed or not, formatted as a question and answer section using `1.` for numbering.

Make sure that the entire module's content is formatted correctly according to the specific 'Markdown' instructions provided for each day. If additional example sentences, explanations, or Spanish phrases are required, you are allowed to create suitable content. Ensure the learning module feels coherent and the examples progressively build upon each day's lesson.
output:
# Advanced Language Learning Module for Spanish: Subjunctive Mood

## Introduction

This week-long lesson plan will focus on the subjunctive mood, a complex grammatical concept in Spanish. The module is targeted at English speakers who have an intermediate grasp of Spanish. Each day's content will be formatted using 'Markdown' with specific configurations to facilitate learning.

## Day 1: Introduction to the Subjunctive Mood

### What is the Subjunctive Mood?

The subjunctive mood is a grammatical mood used to express doubt, uncertainty, wishes, emotions, recommendations, and hypothetical situations. Unlike the indicative mood, which is used to express facts and objective statements, the subjunctive mood expresses subjective or uncertain actions.

> "Es importante que estudies para el examen." (It is important that you study for the exam.)

### Indicative vs Subjunctive

| Indicative | Subjunctive |
|-----------|-------------|
| Quiero ir al cine. (I want to go to the movies.) | Espero que vayas al cine. (I hope you go to the movies.) |
| Creo que ella estudia español. (I believe she studies Spanish.) | Dudo que ella estudie español. (I doubt she studies Spanish.) |
| Es verdad que él trabaja mucho. (It is true that he works a lot.) | No creo que él trabaje tanto. (I don't think he works that much.) |

## Day 2: When to Use the Subjunctive

### Triggers for the Subjunctive

#### Doubt

- Dudar (to doubt)
- No estar seguro/a (to be unsure)
- No creer (to not believe)

#### Emotion

- Alegrarse de (to be happy that)
- Esperar (to hope)
- Temer (to fear)
- Lamentar (to regret)
- Sentir (to feel)

#### Impersonal Expressions

- Es importante que (It is important that)
- Es necesario que (It is necessary that)
- Es mejor que (It is better that)
- Es posible que (It is possible that)
- Es probable que (It is probable that)

***Tip:*** To memorize triggers for the subjunctive, use the acronym WEIRDO: Wishes, Emotions, Impersonal expressions, Recommendations, Doubt, and Ojalá.

## Day 3: Forming the Subjunctive

### Regular Verbs

| Verb | Present Subjunctive |
|------|---------------------|
| Hablar (to speak) | **hable**, hables, hable, hablen |
| Comer (to eat) | **coma**, comas, coma, coman |
| Vivir (to live) | **viva**, vivas, viva, vivan |

### Irregular Verbs

```
Ser (to be)
    sea, seas, sea, sean
Estar (to be)
    esté, estés, esté, estén
Ir (to go)
    vaya, vayas, vaya, vayan
Saber (to know)
    sepa, sepas, sepa, sepan
Dar (to give)
    dé, des, dé, den
```

## Day 4: Subjunctive in Noun Clauses

### Examples

1. No creo que él vaya a la fiesta. (I don't think he is going to the party.)
2. Es posible que llueva mañana. (It is possible that it will rain tomorrow.)
3. Espero que tengas un buen día. (I hope you have a good day.)

<details><summary>Click to expand</summary>

#### Practice Exercises

1. No creo que ella ____(ir) al concierto. (I don't think she is going to the concert.)
    - a. va
    - b. vaya
    - c. fue
    - d. fuera
    - Answer: b. vaya

2. Ojalá que ____(hacer) buen tiempo mañana. (I hope it will be good weather tomorrow.)
    - a. hace
    - b. haga
    - c. hizo
    - d. hiciera
    - Answer: b. haga

3. Es importante que ____(estudiar) para los exámenes. (It is important to study for exams.)
    - a. estudias
    - b. estudie
    - c. estudió
    - d. estudiaría
    - Answer: b. estudie

</details>

## Day 5: Subjunctive in Adjective Clauses

### Adjective Clauses with Subjunctive

An adjective clause is a subordinate clause that modifies a noun or pronoun. When the adjective clause refers to a noun that doesn't exist or whose existence or identity is uncertain, the subjunctive is used.

Example: Busco un hombre que __**(sea)**__ inteligente. (I'm looking for a man who is intelligent.)

### Examples

1. Busco una casa que __**(tenga)**__ un jardín grande. (I'm looking for a house that has a big garden.)
2. Quiero un coche que __**(sea)**__ seguro. (I want a car that is safe.)
3. Necesito un trabajo que __**(pague)**__ bien. (I need a job that pays well.)

![Placeholder Image](#)

## Day 6: Subjunctive in Adverbial Clauses

### Definition

An adverbial clause is a dependent clause that functions as an adverb in a sentence. When the adverbial clause expresses doubt, uncertainty, or a hypothetical situation, the subjunctive is used.

### Conjunctions

- A menos que (unless)
- Antes de que (before)
- Con tal de que (provided that)
- En caso de que (in case)
- Para que (so that)
- Sin que (without)

#### Quiz

- [ ] Quiero que ____(venir) a mi fiesta.
- [ ] Espero que ____(estudiar) para el examen.
- [ ] A menos que ____(llover), iremos al parque.
- [ ] Es necesario que ____(llamar) a mi madre hoy.
- [ ] Sin que el jefe ____(estar) presente, no podemos tomar la decisión final.

Answers: 1. vengas, 2. estudies, 3. llueva, 4. llame, 5. esté

## Day 7: Putting It All Together

### Summary

- The subjunctive mood is used to express doubt, uncertainty, wishes, emotions, recommendations, and hypothetical situations.
- Triggers for the subjunctive include doubt, emotion, impersonal expressions, recommendations, and wishes.
- The subjunctive is formed differently for regular and irregular verbs.
- Noun, adjective, and adverbial clauses can all use the subjunctive mood.

### Dialogue

**Ana:** ¿Qué planes tienes para el fin de semana? (What plans do you have for the weekend?)

**Juan:** Espero que __**(poder)**__ descansar un poco. (I hope I can rest a little.)

**Ana:** Ojalá que __**(hacer)**__ buen tiempo. (I hope it's good weather.)

**Juan:** Si __**(tener)**__ tiempo, me gustaría ir al cine. (If I have time, I would like to go to the movies.)

### Practice Scenarios

1. ¿Crees que ____(llover) hoy? (Do you think it will rain today?)
    - a. Llueve
    - b. Lloverá
    - c. Llueva
    - Answer: c. Llueva

2. Es posible que ____(tener) que trabajar el fin de semana. (It's possible that I have to work on the weekend.)
    - a. Tengo
    - b. Tendré
    - c. Tenga
    - Answer: c. Tenga

3. Quiero un restaurante que ____(ser) bueno y barato. (I want a restaurant that is good and cheap.)
    - a. Sea
    - b. Será
    - c. Es
    - Answer: a. Sea

instruction:
Create an XML file that defines a curriculum for an Intelligent Tutoring System designed for high school mathematics, specifically for algebra and geometry. The curriculum should be tailored for a semester-long course, with the assumption that classes occur five days a week. Each class session is 45 minutes long. The XML file must include the following components:

1. Metadata: Include course title, description, subject, grade level (10th grade), number of units, total number of lessons, and assumed prior knowledge.

2. Units: There shouldBe a minimum of five units. Each unit should cover a distinct topic within algebra or geometry.

3. Lessons: Each unit should include a varying number of lessons. Ensure to enumerate the lesson objectives, materials needed (e.g., textbook pages, software tools), key concepts, lesson activities (e.g., lecture, practice problems, group work), and formative assessment strategies to check for understanding during the lesson.

4. Assessments: Create separate sections for quizzes and tests. Each unit should have at least one quiz and one cumulative test at the end. Specify the assessment format (multiple-choice, open-ended questions, etc.), the number of questions, the topics covered, and any allowed resources.

5. Adaptive Features: Detail at least two adaptive learning strategies implemented by the tutoring system to personalize learning. Examples might include adjusting the difficulty of problems based on student performance or providing tailored feedback.

6. Progress Tracking: Define XML elements to track student progress, including scores on quizzes and tests, completion of lessons, and time spent on each activity.

7. Scheduling: Specify how lessons are scheduled throughout the semester, including makeup sessions for holidays or school events.

Use the following XML structure as a guide, ensuring that each tag is used appropriately and contains the relevant information:

```xml
<Course>
  <MetaData>
    <Title>10th Grade Mathematics: Algebra and Geometry</Title>
    <Description>Comprehensive algebra and geometry course designed for 10th graders to strengthen their mathematical skills and prepare them for advanced math courses.</Description>
    <Subject>Mathematics</Subject>
    <GradeLevel>10th Grade</GradeLevel>
    <UnitsCount>5</UnitsCount>
    <TotalLessons>90</TotalLessons>
    <PriorKnowledge>Basic understanding of arithmetic, simple equations, and basic geometric shapes.</PriorKnowledge>
  </MetaData>

  <Units>
    <!-- Define each unit. Repeat the following structure for each unit. -->
    <Unit id="1">
      <Title>Unit Title</Title>
      <Description>Unit Description</Description>
      <Lessons>
        <!-- Define lessons within the unit. Repeat the following structure for each lesson. -->
        <Lesson id="1.1">
          <Objectives>Lesson Objectives</Objectives>
          <Materials>Materials Needed</Materials>
          <KeyConcepts>Key Concepts</KeyConcepts>
          <Activities>Lesson Activities</Activities>
          <AssessmentStrategies>Formative Assessment Strategies</AssessmentStrategies>
        </Lesson>
        <!-- ... more lessons ... -->
      </Lessons>
      <Assessments>
        <Quiz id="1Q1">
          <!-- Define quiz structure here. -->
        </Quiz>
        <Test id="1T1">
          <!-- Define test structure here. -->
        </Test>
      </Assessments>
    </Unit>
    <!-- ... more units ... -->
  </Units>

  <!-- Define adaptive features. -->
  <AdaptiveFeatures>
    <!-- ... -->
  </AdaptiveFeatures>

  <!-- Add progress tracking system. -->
  <ProgressTracking>
    <!-- ... -->
  </ProgressTracking>

  <!-- Add scheduling system -->
  <Scheduling>
    <!-- ... -->
  </Scheduling>
</Course>
```

Note: You are allowed to make up data for the detailed elements required within each lesson, quiz, test, adaptive feature, and scheduling. Ensure that the XML is well-structured, properly nested, and validates against standard XML schemas. Indentation should reflect the nested structure of the XML elements for readability.
output:
```
<Course>
  <MetaData>
    <Title>10th Grade Mathematics: Algebra and Geometry</Title>
    <Description>Comprehensive algebra and geometry course designed for 10th graders to strengthen their mathematical skills and prepare them for advanced math courses.</Description>
    <Subject>Mathematics</Subject>

        </Lesson>

          <Objectives>Students will be able to factor algebraic expressions.</Objectives>

          <Activities>Lecture, factor tile practice problems, group work</Activities>

    <Unit id="2">
      <Title>Linear Equations</Title>
      <Description>This unit will cover the basics of linear equations, including slope-intercept form and point-slope form.</Description>
      <Lessons>
        <Lesson id="2.1">
          <Objectives>Students will be able to graph linear equations in slope-intercept form.</Objectives>

        </Lesson>

    <Unit id="3">

        </Lesson>
      </Lessons>
      <Assessments>
        <Quiz id="3Q1">
          <Format>Multiple-choice</Format>
          <NumberOfQuestions>10</NumberOfQuestions>
          <TopicsCovered>Factoring, completing the square, quadratic formula</TopicsCovered>

      </Assessments>

    <Unit id="4">

instruction:
Generate a CSV file containing a detailed curriculum for a high school-level Intelligent Tutoring System (ITS) that customizes learning experiences for students in mathematics. The curriculum is to be spread over one semester (roughly 18 weeks). The CSV should include the following columns: 

- `Week`: A numerical value indicating the week of the semester (1 to 18).
- `Topic`: The name of the main topic to be covered.
- `Subtopics`: A list of subtopics to be covered within the main topic, separated by semicolons.
- `Learning Objectives`: Clearly defined objectives for what the student should be able to do after completing the week's material, separated by semicolons.
- `Resource Type`: Type of learning resource provided (e.g., Video, Reading, Interactive Module, Assessment).
- `Resource Title`: The title of the resource.
- `Estimated Time (minutes)`: The estimated time students should spend on the resource.
- `Standards Alignment`: Specific educational standards the week's content aligns with (e.g., Common Core, state standards), separated by semicolons.
- `Adaptive Criteria`: Specify the criteria used to customize the learning path (e.g., Pre-test results, Performance on previous material).
- `Assessment Items`: Include a count of how many assessment items (questions) will be provided.
- `Prerequisites`: Any prior knowledge or skills required before tackling the week’s topic, separated by semicolons.
- `Next Steps`: Briefly describe the next topic or set of skills the student will proceed to.

Use the following dummy topics and subtopics for the first two weeks, then improvise the rest of the curriculum:

Week 1:
- Main Topic: Algebra Fundamentals
- Subtopics: Variables and Expressions; Simple Equations
- Learning Objectives: Understand variables and numerical expressions; Solve simple one-step equations

Week 2:
- Main Topic: Algebra Fundamentals
- Subtopics: Factoring Expressions; Understanding Inequalities
- Learning Objectives: Factor simple expressions; Solve and graph inequalities on a number line

Please ensure that each week follows a logical progression in difficulty and complexity from the previous week, aiming for a smooth learning curve for students. For cell entries that consist of multiple elements, each element must be encapsulated in quotes. The CSV should not contain any headers, footers, or additional notations. The fields within each entry should be enclosed in double quotes and separated by commas (use a backslash to escape any double quotes within the data itself), and line breaks should signify the move to a new week’s entry.

Here is a sample row to illustrate the expected format:

```
"1", "Algebra Fundamentals", "Variables and Expressions; Simple Equations", "Understand variables and numerical expressions; Solve simple one-step equations", "Video", "Introduction to Algebra", "30", "Common Core: HSA-SSE.A.1; Common Core: HSA-SSE.A.2", "Pre-test results", "5", "Basic Arithmetic", "Factoring Expressions"
```

instruction:
Create an intelligent tutoring system (ITS) design document in a YAML format for a hypothetical middle school mathematics course focused on algebra. The system should be configured to offer personalized learning experiences, leveraging adaptive learning algorithms to adjust difficulty based on student performance.

The YAML document should have the following sections and attributes:

1. Title: The name of the ITS.
2. Description: A brief overview of the tutoring system’s capabilities and course content.
3. Target_Audience: Specify the grade level and prerequisites for students.
4. Subjects_Covered: A list of mathematical topics covered in the course.
5. Learning_Objectives: Key outcomes for students, formatted as a numbered list.
6. System_Features: Break this down into the following sub-sections:
   - Adaptive_Learning:
       - Model: The type of adaptive learning model used (e.g., Bayesian Knowledge Tracing, Item Response Theory).
       - Personalization_Criteria: Attributes considered to personalize learning (e.g., prior performance, learning pace).
   - Content_Delivery:
       - Modes: Different content delivery methods used (e.g., video, text-based, interactive simulations).
       - Adaptation_Interval: Frequency of content and difficulty adaptation (e.g., after each module, before a new topic).
   - Assessment:
       - Assessment_Types: Variety of assessments used (e.g., quizzes, homework, real-time questions).
       - Feedback_Mechanism: Description of immediate feedback systems (e.g., hints, explanations).
7. Technical_Requirements:
   - Platform: Whether it's web-based, a desktop application, or mobile.
   - Infrastructure: Details related to backend services (e.g., servers, databases).
   - Compatibility: List of operating systems and any third-party software integrations.
8. User_Interface:
   - Layout: Describe the general layout of the tutoring system.
   - Accessibility_Features: List of features to support users with disabilities.

Include a version number and date of the last update for maintenance purposes. For each section, provide sufficient dummy data to illustrate what real data might look like, but specify that the intelligent tutoring system topic and audience are purely exemplary. Remember to maintain a logical structure in strict YAML format with proper indentation and use of hyphens and colons.
output:
# Version: 1.0
# Last Updated: 10/31/2021

title: Middle School Algebra Intelligent Tutoring System
description: A personalized learning system designed for middle school students to learn algebra.
target_audience: 
  grade_level: 7th and 8th grade
  prerequisites: Basic arithmetic operations, fractions, and decimals
subjects_covered: 
  - Expressions and Equations
  - Linear Functions
  - Quadratic Functions
  - Exponential Functions
  - Polynomials
  - Factoring and Simplification 
  - Systems of Equations
  - Inequalities and Absolute Value
learning_objectives: 
  - Students will be able to solve linear equations with one variable.
  - Students will understand the concept of slope and how to find it for a given line.
  - Students will be able to solve quadratic equations using factoring and the quadratic formula.
  - Students will understand the concept of exponential growth and decay and how to model it mathematically.
  - Students will be able to multiply and factorize polynomials.
system_features: 
  adaptive_learning: 
    model: Bayesian Knowledge Tracing
    personalization_criteria: 
      - Prior performance on assessments
      - Learning pace
  content_delivery: 
    modes: 
      - Video lectures
      - Interactive simulations
      - Text-based learning
    adaptation_interval: After each module
  assessment: 
    assessment_types: 
      - Quizzes
      - Homework assignments
      - Real-time questions during class
    feedback_mechanism: 
      - Hints
      - Explanations
technical_requirements: 
  platform: Web-based
  infrastructure: 
    - Servers: 2 servers with 8GB RAM, 250GB storage
    - Databases: MySQL 8.0
  compatibility: 
    - Operating Systems: Windows, Mac OS, Linux
    - Third-party software integrations: Google Classroom, Zoom
user_interface: 
  layout: 
    - Dashboard with progress reports
    - Learning modules with interactive simulations and video lectures
    - Quizzes and homework assignments
  accessibility_features: 
    - Closed captioning for videos
    - Screen reader compatibility

instruction:
Craft a comprehensive lesson plan in Markdown format for an Intelligent Tutoring System (ITS) intended to educate high school students in Algebra II on the topic of "Complex Numbers." The plan should cater to different learning styles and include adaptive learning pathways.

### Lesson Plan: Algebra II - Complex Numbers

#### Overview 
_Provide an abstract of the lesson, including the objectives and key concepts to be covered._

```markdown
# Learning Objectives

By the end of this lesson, students should be able to:

1. Define and explain what complex numbers are.
2. Perform basic operations with complex numbers (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division).
3. Represent complex numbers graphically on the complex plane.
4. Solve quadratic equations with complex solutions.

# Key Concepts

- Imaginary unit (i)
- Complex number (a + bi)
- Complex plane
- Operations with complex numbers
- Modulus of a complex number
- Arguments and polar form of complex numbers
```

#### Instructional Content
_Create detailed instructional content with examples, definitions, and explanations._

```markdown
## Introduction to Complex Numbers

Complex numbers are numbers of the form `a + bi` where `a` and `b` are real numbers and `i` is the imaginary unit with the property `i^2 = -1`.

**Example:**
1. `3 + 4i` is a complex number where `3` is the real part and `4i` is the imaginary part.

## Operations with Complex Numbers

### Addition
To add two complex numbers, add their real parts and imaginary parts separately.

**Example:**
`(2 + 3i) + (1 + 2i) = (2 + 1) + (3i + 2i) = 3 + 5i`

### Subtraction
...

### Multiplication
...

### Division
...

## Graphical Representation on the Complex Plane
...

## Solving Quadratic Equations with Complex Solutions
...
```

#### Learning Activities
_Organize different types of learning activities such as quizzes, interactive simulations, and group discussions that cater to auditory, visual, and kinesthetic learners._

```markdown
# Quizzes

Multiple-choice and fill-in-the-blank questions on concepts and operations surrounding complex numbers.

# Interactive Simulations

Use a tool such as [Desmos](https://www.desmos.com/calculator) to allow students to interactively explore the complex plane and visualize complex number operations.

# Group Discussions

Facilitate discussions on the relevance of complex numbers in real-world contexts and how they might be used in various fields.
```

#### Adaptive Learning Pathways
_Describe two separate learning pathways for students struggling with concepts and for students who quickly master the initial material._

```markdown
## Remedial Pathway
If students score below 70% on the initial quiz:

1. Review the Introduction to Complex Numbers.
2. Offer additional practice problems with step-by-step feedback.
3. Schedule a one-on-one tutoring session to address specific difficulties.

## Accelerated Pathway
For students who score above 90% on the initial quiz:

1. Introduce more complex operations such as finding the nth roots of complex numbers.
2. Assign problems that involve applications of complex numbers in physics and engineering.
3. Encourage exploration of complex number theory.
```

#### Assessment
_Develop both formative and summative assessment methods to evaluate student understanding throughout and after the lesson._

```markdown
# Formative Assessment

Students will complete short quizzes after each major section to assess understanding of content just covered.

# Summative Assessment

At the end of the unit, students will take a comprehensive test that includes:

- Definitions and explanations.
- Problem-solving questions.
- Application questions.

Example Problem: Solve for x in the equation `x^2 + 1 = 0` using complex numbers.

```

#### Reflection and Feedback
_Outline a structured reflection activity and feedback mechanism for students to self-assess and receive feedback on their learning._

```markdown
# Reflection

Have students write a brief paragraph answering the following questions:

- What was the most challenging concept in this lesson?
- How do you see complex numbers being used outside of the mathematics classroom?

# Feedback

Students will receive personalized feedback on both formative and summative assessments by the ITS, highlighting strengths and areas for improvement.

```

#### Additional Resources
_Provide a list of additional resources such as textbooks, websites, and videos for students who wish to delve deeper into the topic._

```markdown
- [Khan Academy: Complex Numbers](https://www.khanacademy.org/math/algebra2)
- [3Blue1Brown: Complex Numbers Series](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL...)
- Textbook: Algebra II by [Author Name], [Publication Year]
```

#### Accommodations for Special Needs
_Detail accommodations for students with special needs such as extended time for assessments, text-to-speech for reading materials, and alternative formats for instructional content._

```markdown
# Accommodations

1. Extended time on quizzes and tests for students with an IEP for extended time.
2. Instructional materials provided in text-to-speech format.
3. Interactive simulations compatible with screen reading software.
```

 According to the information above 
 - You need to fill in the sections with ellipses (e.g., Operations with Complex Numbers – Subtraction, Multiplication, Division) with relevant instructional content.
- Create example problems and solutions within each section.
- Devise assessments with keys for automatic grading.
- Modify the additional resources with actual links and references, ensuring they are current and suitable for the intended high school audience.
- In case of missing information or data, you have the autonomy to improvise based on typical high school Algebra II curriculum standards.
output:
### Lesson Plan: Algebra II - Complex Numbers

#### Overview 
In this lesson, students will learn about complex numbers and their operations. They will also be introduced to the graphical representation of complex numbers on the complex plane and how to solve quadratic equations with complex solutions. By the end of the lesson, students will be able to define and explain complex numbers, perform basic operations with them, represent them graphically, and solve quadratic equations with complex solutions.

```markdown
# Learning Objectives

By the end of this lesson, students should be able to:

1. Define and explain what complex numbers are.
2. Perform basic operations with complex numbers (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division).
3. Represent complex numbers graphically on the complex plane.
4. Solve quadratic equations with complex solutions.

# Key Concepts

- Imaginary unit (i)
- Complex number (a + bi)
- Complex plane
- Operations with complex numbers
- Modulus of a complex number
- Arguments and polar form of complex numbers
```

#### Instructional Content
##### Introduction to Complex Numbers

Complex numbers are numbers of the form `a + bi` where `a` and `b` are real numbers and `i` is the imaginary unit with the property `i^2 = -1`.

**Example:**
1. `3 + 4i` is a complex number where `3` is the real part and `4i` is the imaginary part.

##### Operations with Complex Numbers
###### Addition
To add two complex numbers, add their real parts and imaginary parts separately.

**Example:**
`(2 + 3i) + (1 + 2i) = (2 + 1) + (3i + 2i) = 3 + 5i`

###### Subtraction
To subtract two complex numbers, subtract their real parts and imaginary parts separately.

**Example:**
`(2 + 3i) - (1 + 2i) = (2 - 1) + (3i - 2i) = 1 + i`

###### Multiplication
To multiply two complex numbers, use the distributive property and the fact that `i^2 = -1`.

**Example:**
`(2 + 3i)(1 + 2i) = 2 + 4i + 3i + 6i^2 = -4 + 10i`

###### Division
To divide two complex numbers, multiply the numerator and denominator by the complex conjugate of the denominator.

**Example:**
`(2 + 3i)/(1 + 2i) = (2 + 3i)(1 - 2i)/(1 + 2i)(1 - 2i) = (-4 + 7i)/5`

##### Graphical Representation on the Complex Plane
A complex number can be represented as a point on the complex plane, where the horizontal axis represents the real part and the vertical axis represents the imaginary part. The modulus of a complex number is the distance from the origin to the point representing the complex number, and the argument is the angle between the positive real axis and the line connecting the origin to the point representing the complex number.

###### Modulus of a Complex Number
The modulus of a complex number `a + bi` is `|a + bi| = sqrt(a^2 + b^2)`.

**Example:**
`|3 + 4i| = sqrt(3^2 + 4^2) = 5`

###### Arguments and Polar Form of Complex Numbers
The argument of a complex number `a + bi` can be found using the formula `arg(a + bi) = tan^-1(b/a)`. The polar form of a complex number is the form `r(cos(theta) + i sin(theta))`, where `r` is the modulus and `theta` is the argument.

**Example:**
The polar form of `3 + 4i` is `5(cos(53.13) + i sin(53.13))`.

##### Solving Quadratic Equations with Complex Solutions
To solve a quadratic equation of the form `ax^2 + bx + c = 0` with complex solutions, use the quadratic formula `x = (-b ± sqrt(b^2 - 4ac))/(2a)` and substitute `b^2 - 4ac < 0`.

**Example:**
Solve for `x` in the equation `x^2 + 1 = 0`.

`x = ±sqrt(-1) = ±i`

#### Learning Activities
##### Quizzes
Multiple-choice and fill-in-the-blank questions on concepts and operations surrounding complex numbers.

**Example:**
What is the modulus of the complex number `4 - 3i`?
A. 5
B. 7
C. 9
D. 12

Answer: A. 5

##### Interactive Simulations
Use a tool such as [Desmos](https://www.desmos.com/calculator) to allow students to interactively explore the complex plane and visualize complex number operations.

##### Group Discussions
Facilitate discussions on the relevance of complex numbers in real-world contexts and how they might be used in various fields.

#### Adaptive Learning Pathways
##### Remedial Pathway
If students score below 70% on the initial quiz:

1. Review the Introduction to Complex Numbers.
2. Offer additional practice problems with step-by-step feedback.
3. Schedule a one-on-one tutoring session to address specific difficulties.

##### Accelerated Pathway
For students who score above 90% on the initial quiz:

1. Introduce more complex operations such as finding the nth roots of complex numbers.
2. Assign problems that involve applications of complex numbers in physics and engineering.
3. Encourage exploration of complex number theory.

#### Assessment
##### Formative Assessment
Students will complete short quizzes after each major section to assess understanding of content just covered.

**Example:**
What is the argument of the complex number `2 - 3i`?
A. -0.93
B. 0.93
C. -1.23
D. 1.23

Answer: A. -0.93

##### Summative Assessment
At the end of the unit, students will take a comprehensive test that includes:

- Definitions and explanations.
- Problem-solving questions.
- Application questions.

Example Problem: Solve for `x` in the equation `x^2 + 4x + 5 = 0` using complex numbers.

Answer: `x = -2 + i, -2 - i`

#### Reflection and Feedback
##### Reflection
Have students write a brief paragraph answering the following questions:

- What was the most challenging concept in this lesson?
- How do you see complex numbers being used outside of the mathematics classroom?

##### Feedback
Students will receive personalized feedback on both formative and summative assessments by the ITS, highlighting strengths and areas for improvement.

#### Additional Resources
- [Khan Academy: Complex Numbers](https://www.khanacademy.org/math/algebra2/introduction-to-complex-numbers-alg2)
- [3Blue1Brown: Complex Numbers Series](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLZHQObOWTQDPD3MizzM2xVFitgF8hE_ab)
- Textbook: Algebra II by Ron Larson, Laurie Boswell, and Timothy D. Kanold (2013)

#### Accommodations for Special Needs
##### Accommodations
1. Extended time on quizzes and tests for students with an IEP for extended time.
2. Instructional materials provided in text-to-speech format.
3. Interactive simulations compatible with screen reading software.

instruction:
Create an automated grading system tailored for a high school level multiple choice and short answer history exam. The grading system should process student answers, compute scores, provide feedback on each question, and highlight topics for further review. The output should be in the form of a JSON object for each student. Follow these specific JSON format requirements:

1. "studentId": A unique identifier for the student.
2. "examCode": A unique identifier for the exam.
3. "responses": An array of JSON objects where each object contains:
   - "questionId": Unique identifier for the question.
   - "response": The student's response.
   - "score": An object with "awarded" for points awarded and "possible" for possible points.
   - "correctAnswer": The correct answer to the question.
   - "feedback": A short text providing feedback on the student’s response.
4. "totalScore": An object with "earned" for total points earned and "outOf" for total possible points.
5. "comments": An optional general text field for additional feedback on the exam.
6. "subjectsForReview": An array of subject topics the student should review, based on the incorrectly answered questions.

The system needs to accommodate for two types of questions: multiple-choice with a single correct answer, and short answer questions that may have keywords/phrases indicative of a correct response. A student should be awarded full points for a correct multiple-choice answer and partial to full points for a short answer based on the presence of key concepts or phrases in the response.

Here's the required structure for your JSON output:

```json
{
  "studentId": "string",
  "examCode": "string",
  "responses": [
    {
      "questionId": "string",
      "response": "string",
      "score": {
        "awarded": "number",
        "possible": "number"
      },
      "correctAnswer": "string",
      "feedback": "string"
    },
    ...
  ],
  "totalScore": {
    "earned": "number",
    "outOf": "number"
  },
  "comments": "string",
  "subjectsForReview": ["string", ...]
}
```

Use the following dummy context/data to generate the output:
- Student ID: HS123456
- Exam Code: HIST2023MC
- Question IDs for multiple choice questions: MCQ1, MCQ2, MCQ3
- Question IDs for short answer questions: SAQ1, SAQ2
- Correct answers for multiple-choice questions: A, B, C
- Key concepts for the short answer questions should be "Revolution" for SAQ1 and "Constitution" for SAQ2
- Assume the student's responses to the multiple-choice questions are A, C, B and for the short answer questions: "The revolution was a significant period." and "The constitution was written to establish justice."

Multiple-choice questions are worth 1 point each. Short answer questions have a gradation of points:
- Mentioning the correct concept but with limited explanation: 2 points.
- A detailed explanation and mention of the concept: 4 points.

The total possible points for the exam are 10. Provide brief feedback on each response indicating if the answer was correct or, if not, a suggestion for improvement. Add any two topics to the "subjectsForReview" field that are based on the content linked to the questions the student answered incorrectly or with limited detail. For any information not provided here, improvise as necessary. Ensure that no preliminary or concluding statements are included in the output—only the formatted JSON object.

Design and generate an XML schema definition (XSD) for an automated grading system that processes student essays. This schema should include the following components and constraints:

1. **Student Information:**
   - Student ID (an alphanumeric string)
   - Full Name (first name, middle name, optional, and last name)
   - Birthdate (in YYYY-MM-DD format)
   - Class (a string representing their current class or grade)

2. **Essay Submission:**
   - Submission ID (a unique alphanumeric string)
   - Submission Timestamp (ISO 8601 format)
   - File Reference (a string path to the file location)
   - Word Count (an integer)
   - List of key phrases (an array of strings)
   - Originality score (a decimal between 0 and 1, with 1 being completely original)

3. **Grading Criteria:**
   - Category (e.g., "Content", "Structure", "Creativity")
   - Maximum Points (an integer)
   - Score Earned (a decimal)
   - Comments (an optional text field for tutor's remarks)

4. **Final Grade:**
   - Total Score (a decimal)
   - Grade Letter (a character from A-F)
   - Feedback Summary (a longer text field)

The XML schema should enforce appropriate data types and constraints, such as non-null fields where mandatory and specific formats for timestamps and IDs. Elements should include annotations documenting their meaning and any constraints that apply to them.

In addition, create a sample XML file that conforms to your schema representing a single student's essay submission. This XML file should include the following dummy data, with identifiers and data details that are appropriately constructed to illustrate the XML schema's usage:

- Student Information:
  - Student ID: "X123456"
  - Full Name: "Jane A. Doe"
  - Birthdate: "2005-04-12"
  - Class: "10th Grade English"

- Essay Submission:
  - Submission ID: "ESSAY2023031501"
  - Submission Timestamp: "2023-03-15T14:22:05Z"
  - File Reference: "/submissions/2023/03/ESSAY2023031501.docx"
  - Word Count: 1250
  - Key Phrases: ["To Kill a Mockingbird", "Coming of age", "Social Injustice"]
  - Originality Score: 0.89

- Grading Criteria:
  - Category: Content
  - Maximum Points: 30
  - Score Earned: 25.5
  - Comments: "Excellent analysis of the themes."

  - (Include at least two more categories with corresponding scores and comments.)

- Final Grade: 
  - Total Score: 87.5
  - Grade Letter: "B+"
  - Feedback Summary: "Great work, but there's room for improvement in your writing structure."

Finally, ensure that your provided XML completely complies with the defined schema. If any required dummy data details are not specified in this prompt, you have the creative liberty to generate and include appropriate values for those elements.
output:
XML Schema Definition (XSD):

```
<xs:schema xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">
  
  <!-- Student Information -->
  <xs:element name="student">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element name="id" type="xs:string"/>
        <xs:element name="full_name">
          <xs:complexType>
            <xs:sequence>
              <xs:element name="first_name" type="xs:string"/>
              <xs:element name="middle_name" type="xs:string" minOccurs="0"/>
              <xs:element name="last_name" type="xs:string"/>
            </xs:sequence>
          </xs:complexType>
        </xs:element>
        <xs:element name="birthdate" type="xs:date"/>
        <xs:element name="class" type="xs:string"/>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>

  <!-- Essay Submission -->
  <xs:element name="essay_submission">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element name="submission_id" type="xs:string"/>
        <xs:element name="submission_timestamp" type="xs:dateTime"/>
        <xs:element name="file_reference" type="xs:string"/>
        <xs:element name="word_count" type="xs:integer"/>
        <xs:element name="key_phrases">
          <xs:complexType>
            <xs:sequence>
              <xs:element name="key_phrase" type="xs:string" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
            </xs:sequence>
          </xs:complexType>
        </xs:element>
        <xs:element name="originality_score" type="xs:decimal" minInclusive="0" maxInclusive="1"/>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>

  <!-- Grading Criteria -->
  <xs:element name="grading_criteria">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element name="category" type="xs:string"/>
        <xs:element name="maximum_points" type="xs:integer"/>
        <xs:element name="score_earned" type="xs:decimal"/>
        <xs:element name="comments" type="xs:string" minOccurs="0"/>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>

  <!-- Final Grade -->
  <xs:element name="final_grade">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element name="total_score" type="xs:decimal"/>
        <xs:element name="grade_letter" type="xs:string"/>
        <xs:element name="feedback_summary" type="xs:string"/>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>

  <!-- Root Element -->
  <xs:element name="automated_grading_system">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element ref="student"/>
        <xs:element ref="essay_submission"/>
        <xs:element name="grading_criteria" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
        <xs:element ref="final_grade"/>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>

</xs:schema>
```

Sample XML File:

instruction:
Create a CSV file that represents the automated grading report for a high school algebra final exam. The output should include the following columns:

- StudentID: A unique identifier for each student, consisting of 7 random alphanumeric characters.
- FullName: Students' full names in the format "Last, First".
- ClassSection: Alphanumeric code designating their class section, e.g., "10A", "10B", etc.
- MultipleChoice: Scores for the multiple-choice section out of 40 points, showing only the numeric score.
- WordProblems: Scores for the word problems section out of 30 points, showing only the numeric score.
- DataAnalysis: Scores for the data analysis section out of 20 points, showing only the numeric score.
- BonusPoints: Any extra credit points, up to 5, showing only the numeric score.
- TotalScore: A calculated field representing the sum of the MultipleChoice, WordProblems, DataAnalysis, and BonusPoints, up to 95 points.
- LetterGrade: The letter grade corresponding to the TotalScore: A (90-100), B (80-89), C (70-79), D (60-69), and F (0-59).
- Comments: Any remarks regarding the student's performance. Limit the length to 100 characters.

Ensure the CSV file adheres to the following specific configurations:

- No header or footer in the CSV.
- Each field should be enclosed in double quotes.
- Fields should be separated by a comma without any spaces.
- Newlines signify the end of a student's record.
- Ensure that numerical scores are correct to two decimal places (e.g., "87.00" for a score of 87).
- The Comments column should include the note "Great improvement" for students whose score is at least 20 points higher than the class average and "Needs review" for those 15 points below the class average.

You are allowed to create dummy data for a class of 5 students. Pay close attention to numeric fields and ensure they are consistent and reflective of typical student performance variations. You are also free to improvise on any other specific details not mentioned.

Output the CSV content as plain text.

instruction:
Create a YAML configuration for an automated grading system that is designed to evaluate English essay responses for a high school proficiency test. The system should be equipped to grade based on the following criteria:

1. Coherence and Cohesion: The essay should be well-organized with clear progression of ideas.
2. Vocabulary Range: The essay should demonstrate a variety of vocabulary appropriate to the academic context.
3. Grammatical Range and Accuracy: The essay should use a range of grammatical structures accurately.
4. Task Achievement: The essay should completely address all parts of the prompt.

The configuration must include the following components:

- Metadata: Includes the version of the grading system, date of configuration, and author information.
- Rubric: Details each of the grading criteria with point ranges. Define a four-tier point system (0-3 points for each criterion).
- Thresholds: Specify the passing threshold and the distinction threshold.
- Weightage: Assign weightage to each criterion with respect to total score calculation.
- FeedbackTemplates: Configure automatic feedback comments for different score ranges within each criterion.
- ExceptionHandling: Define rules for handling common exceptions such as off-topic essays, plagiarism detection, and word count requirements.
- ReportFormat: Define the structure for the final report that should include the total score, detailed scores per criterion, and personalized feedback.

For the sake of this configuration, assume that the total score is out of 100 and that each criterion carries equal weightage. 

In cases where you lack context or data, feel free to improvise and include plausible assumptions in your configuration. Your YAML configuration must be structured with proper indentation, use of dashboards for lists, and key-value pairs for attributes. It should also adhere to being human-readable and easily interpreted by stakeholders of varying technical proficiencies.

Here is an example of how a section of the YAML file might be structured:

```yaml
Metadata:
  Version: "2.1"
  Date: "2023-04-01"
  Author:
    Name: "John Doe"
    Contact: "john.doe@email.com"
```

Please note: The above structure is part of the prompt and should be used to continue creating the rest of the YAML configuration.
output:
```yaml
Metadata:
  Version: "1.0"
  Date: "2021-10-01"
  Author:
    Name: "Jane Smith"
    Contact: "jane.smith@email.com"

Rubric:
  - Criterion: Coherence and Cohesion
    PointRanges:
      - Range: 0-1
        Description: The essay lacks organization and progression of ideas.
      - Range: 2
        Description: The essay is somewhat organized but lacks clear progression of ideas.
      - Range: 3
        Description: The essay is well-organized with clear progression of ideas.
  - Criterion: Vocabulary Range

      - Range: 0-1
        Description: The essay demonstrates a limited range of vocabulary.
      - Range: 2
        Description: The essay demonstrates some variety of vocabulary appropriate to the academic context.
      - Range: 3
        Description: The essay demonstrates a wide range of vocabulary appropriate to the academic context.
  - Criterion: Grammatical Range and Accuracy
    PointRanges:
      - Range: 0-1
        Description: The essay uses a limited range of grammatical structures and contains many errors.
      - Range: 2
        Description: The essay uses some variety of grammatical structures with some errors.
      - Range: 3
        Description: The essay uses a range of grammatical structures accurately.
  - Criterion: Task Achievement
    PointRanges:
      - Range: 0-1
        Description: The essay does not address all parts of the prompt.
      - Range: 2
        Description: The essay partially addresses all parts of the prompt.
      - Range: 3
        Description: The essay completely addresses all parts of the prompt.

Thresholds:
  Passing: 60
  Distinction: 90

Weightage:
  Coherence and Cohesion: 25
  Vocabulary Range: 25
  Grammatical Range and Accuracy: 25
  Task Achievement: 25

FeedbackTemplates:
  - Criterion: Coherence and Cohesion
    PointRanges:
      - Range: 0-1
        Feedback: "Your essay lacks organization and progression of ideas. Please work on developing a clear structure for your essay."
      - Range: 2
        Feedback: "Your essay is somewhat organized but could benefit from clearer progression of ideas. Consider using transitional phrases to guide the reader."
      - Range: 3
        Feedback: "Your essay is well-organized with clear progression of ideas. Great job!"
  - Criterion: Vocabulary Range
    PointRanges:
      - Range: 0-1
        Feedback: "Your essay demonstrates a limited range of vocabulary. Consider using a thesaurus to find synonyms for commonly used words."
      - Range: 2
        Feedback: "Your essay demonstrates some variety of vocabulary appropriate to the academic context. Try incorporating more subject-specific terminology."
      - Range: 3
        Feedback: "Your essay demonstrates a wide range of vocabulary appropriate to the academic context. Excellent work!"
  - Criterion: Grammatical Range and Accuracy
    PointRanges:
      - Range: 0-1
        Feedback: "Your essay uses a limited range of grammatical structures and contains many errors. Please review grammar rules and practice writing more sentences."
      - Range: 2
        Feedback: "Your essay uses some variety of grammatical structures with some errors. Keep practicing to improve your accuracy."
      - Range: 3
        Feedback: "Your essay uses a range of grammatical structures accurately. Well done!"
  - Criterion: Task Achievement
    PointRanges:
      - Range: 0-1
        Feedback: "Your essay does not address all parts of the prompt. Make sure to read the prompt carefully and include all required elements."
      - Range: 2
        Feedback: "Your essay partially addresses all parts of the prompt. Try to provide more detailed responses for each part."
      - Range: 3
        Feedback: "Your essay completely addresses all parts of the prompt. Great job!"

ExceptionHandling:
  OffTopic:
    PointReduction: 50
    Feedback: "Your essay is off-topic and will receive a reduced score."
  Plagiarism:
    PointReduction: 0
    Feedback: "Your essay contains plagiarized content and cannot be graded. Please submit an original essay."
  WordCount:
    Minimum: 250
    Maximum: 500
    Feedback: "Your essay does not meet the required word count. Please revise to meet the minimum and maximum requirements."

ReportFormat:
  - TotalScore
  - CriterionScores
  - PersonalizedFeedback
```

instruction:
Design and detail a comprehensive blueprint for an Automated Essay Grading System in the education sector. The documentation must be formatted in Markdown, and should follow these specifics:

1. **Header structure**:
   - Title (## Title):
     "Automated Essay Grading System (AEGS) Design Document"
   - Introduction (### Introduction)
   - System Overview (### System Overview)
   - Technical Architecture (### Technical Architecture)
     - Data Collection (#### Data Collection)
     - Machine Learning Model (#### Machine Learning Model)
     - Natural Language Processing (#### Natural Language Processing)
   - Implementation Plan (### Implementation Plan)
     - Phase 1: Proof of Concept (#### Phase 1: Proof of Concept)
     - Phase 2: Pilot Testing (#### Phase 2: Pilot Testing)
     - Phase 3: Full-scale Deployment (#### Phase 3: Full-scale Deployment)
   - Evaluation Criteria (### Evaluation Criteria)
   - Limitations and Ethical Considerations (### Limitations and Ethical Considerations)
   - Conclusion (### Conclusion)

2. **Formatting Guidelines**:
   - **Bold** for section headings and subheadings.
   - *Italicize* any terms that are not generally known.
   - Inline `code` format should be used when referencing specific variables or code snippets related to the grading algorithm.
   - Bulleted lists for features or requirements.
   - Numbered lists for step-by-step guides or processes.
   - Blockquotes for large quotations or excerpts from academic papers.
   - Hyperlinks for all external references - ensure that they are formatted as [anchor text](URL).

3. **Content Specifics**:
   - **Introduction**: Provide a brief overview of the need for automated essay grading systems.
   - **System Overview**: Explain the general working mechanism for the AEGS.
   - **Technical Architecture**: Include a detailed description using the following structure:
     - **Data Collection**: Describe the sources and types of data needed.
     - **Machine Learning Model**: Define the model to be used and justify the choice.
     - **Natural Language Processing**: Outline the NLP techniques that will be applied in grading essays.
   - **Implementation Plan**: Elaborate on the three phases of implementation, including timelines, required resources, and milestones.
   - **Evaluation Criteria**: Set forth the metrics on how the essays will be evaluated by the system.
   - **Limitations and Ethical Considerations**: Discuss any potential biases, privacy concerns, and mitigation strategies.
   - **Conclusion**: Summarize the system’s potential impact on the educational landscape.

4. **Imaginary Data**:
   Feel free to create imaginary datasets, studies, or references where necessary, ensuring they are realistic and consistent within the scope of automated grading systems (e.g., dataset sizes, types of essays, performance metrics).

5. **Code Snippets**:
   Include a few Python pseudo-code snippets as examples for how data preprocessing or feature extraction might be done in the system. Ensure proper Markdown code block formatting with syntax highlighting as follows:

   ```python
   # This is a Python code snippet example
   def preprocess_text(text):
       # Code to preprocess text
       pass
   ```

The final document should be comprehensive, technically detailed, and elegantly formatted such that it can be directly used as a formal proposal for building an Automated Essay Grading System. In cases where you lack context or data, feel free to improvise and include plausible assumptions.
output:
## Automated Essay Grading System (AEGS) Design Document

### Introduction

Automated Essay Grading Systems (AEGS) have become increasingly popular in the education sector due to their potential to provide efficient and objective grading of essays. These systems use machine learning algorithms to evaluate essays based on various criteria, including grammar, syntax, content, and structure. AEGS can significantly reduce the workload for teachers and provide students with immediate feedback, improving the overall learning experience.

### System Overview

The AEGS will use a combination of machine learning models and natural language processing techniques to grade essays. The system will take in essays as input and output a score based on predefined criteria. The system will use a pre-trained machine learning model to evaluate the essays, which will be fine-tuned using a dataset of graded essays. Natural language processing techniques such as tokenization and part-of-speech tagging will be applied to the essays to extract relevant features for grading.

### Technical Architecture

#### Data Collection

The AEGS will require a dataset of essays for training and testing the machine learning model. The dataset should contain a diverse set of essays covering different topics, writing styles, and levels of complexity. The dataset should be curated to ensure that it is representative of the student population. The essays should be labeled with scores to enable the model to learn from the data.

#### Machine Learning Model

The AEGS will use a deep neural network model for grading essays. The model will be trained on a large dataset of essays using a supervised learning approach. The model will be fine-tuned using transfer learning techniques to adapt to the specific grading criteria of the institution. The model will take in preprocessed essays and output a score based on predefined criteria. The model will be evaluated using various performance metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score.

#### Natural Language Processing

The AEGS will use natural language processing techniques to preprocess the essays and extract relevant features for grading. The essays will be tokenized, and part-of-speech tags will be assigned to each token. The system will also perform feature extraction to identify relevant features such as sentence length, word frequency, and syntactic complexity. The extracted features will be used as input to the machine learning model.

### Implementation Plan

#### Phase 1: Proof of Concept

In the first phase, we will develop a proof of concept to demonstrate the feasibility of the AEGS. We will curate a small dataset of essays and train a simple machine learning model to grade them. We will evaluate the performance of the model using basic performance metrics such as accuracy and precision. This phase will take approximately two months to complete.

#### Phase 2: Pilot Testing

In the second phase, we will conduct pilot testing of the AEGS using a larger dataset of essays. We will fine-tune the machine learning model using transfer learning techniques and evaluate its performance using standard performance metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. We will also conduct user acceptance testing to evaluate the usability of the system. This phase will take approximately six months to complete.

#### Phase 3: Full-scale Deployment

In the final phase, we will deploy the AEGS in a production environment. We will integrate the system with the institution's learning management system and train the model on a larger dataset of essays. We will also perform regular maintenance and updates to ensure that the system remains up-to-date and effective. This phase will take approximately twelve months to complete.

### Evaluation Criteria

The AEGS will be evaluated based on several criteria, including accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. The system's ability to provide immediate feedback to students and reduce the workload for teachers will also be evaluated. The system's ability to adapt to different grading criteria and handle a diverse set of essays will also be considered.

### Limitations and Ethical Considerations

The AEGS may have certain limitations and ethical considerations that need to be addressed. The system may be biased towards certain types of essays or writing styles, which may affect the accuracy of the grading. The system may also have privacy concerns, as it will require access to student essays. To address these concerns, we will ensure that the system is transparent and explainable, and we will implement appropriate privacy measures to protect student data.

### Conclusion

The AEGS has the potential to revolutionize the way essays are graded in the education sector. The system can provide efficient and objective grading, reducing the workload for teachers and providing immediate feedback to students. The AEGS can also adapt to different grading criteria and handle a diverse set of essays. With careful planning and implementation, the AEGS can be an effective tool for improving the overall learning experience.

instruction:
Generate a detailed JSON report that analyzes the performance of students in different departments within a university over the last academic year. The JSON output should include aggregated data across departments, showcasing average grades, departmental ranking based on the average GPA, percentage of students who passed/failed, and any notable trends or patterns in performance across different semesters.

Requirements for the JSON format:

1. The report should be encapsulated within a top-level JSON object.
2. Each department should be represented as a unique object within an array labelled `departments`.
3. Each department object must include the following details:
   - `departmentName`: A string indicating the name of the department.
   - `averageGPA`: A float value representing the average GPA of students in the department, calculated to two decimal points.
   - `totalStudents`: An integer indicating the total number of students in the department.
   - `passRate`: A float value representing the percentage of students who passed, calculated to two decimal points.
   - `failRate`: A float value representing the percentage of students who failed, calculated to two decimal points.
   - `semesterTrends`: An array of objects, each presenting data for a different semester (e.g., `{"semester": "Fall 2022", "averageGPA": 3.2}`).
4. Include a separate array labelled `departmentRankings` which ranks departments by their average GPA. Each object within the array should contain:
   - `rank`: An integer indicating the rank of the department.
   - `departmentName`: A string corresponding to the department's name.
   - `averageGPA`: As described above.
5. Include a summary object within the main object with:
   - `totalAverageGPA`: The overall average GPA across all departments.
   - `highestGPA`: The highest recorded average GPA among all departments.
   - `lowestGPA`: The lowest recorded average GPA among all departments.
6. The JSON must be formatted with proper indentation for readability and correctly handle all necessary escaping where applicable.

You are allowed to make up realistic data for the departments, student populations, and GPA distributions. Base your data generation on the assumption that the university has a total of 10 departments and that the GPA scale runs from 0.0 to 4.0.

Note: Be sure that the dataset is consistent within itself (i.e., the `totalAverageGPA` is correctly calculated from department averages, and the rankings in `departmentRankings` reflect the averages stated within the `departments` array).

Here is a starter template for your JSON:

```json
{
  "departments": [
    {
      "departmentName": "",
      "averageGPA": 0.00,
      "totalStudents": 0,
      "passRate": 0.00,
      "failRate": 0.00,
      "semesterTrends": [
        {
          "semester": "",
          "averageGPA": 0.00
        }
        // Repeat objects for each semester
      ]
    }
    // Repeat objects for each department
  ],
  "departmentRankings": [
    {
      "rank": 1,
      "departmentName": "",
      "averageGPA": 0.00
    }
    // Repeat objects ranked by average GPA
  ],
  "summary": {
    "totalAverageGPA": 0.00,
    "highestGPA": 0.00,
    "lowestGPA": 0.00
  }
}
```

Generate a detailed XML report on the performance of students in a high school over the last academic year. This report should include the following information:

1. A summary section that includes:
   - The total number of students
   - The average GPA for the entire student body
   - Breakdown of students in terms of performance categories (e.g., 'Excellent', 'Good', 'Average', 'Poor')

2. A detailed section for each grade (9-12) that includes:
   - The number of students per grade
   - The average GPA for the grade
   - The highest GPA in the grade
   - The lowest GPA in the grade

3. A section for student extracurricular activities including:
   - The number of students participating in at least one extracurricular activity
   - A list of all extracurricular activities available
   - The number of students participating in each activity

4. A final analysis section that suggests possible correlations between extracurricular participation and academic performance.

The XML structure should strictly adhere to the following format:

- Root element should be <SchoolPerformanceReport>
- Each section should be encapsulated by respective parent elements like <Summary>, <GradeDetails>, and <ExtracurricularActivities>
- Within <GradeDetails>, each grade should be a child element named <Grade> with an attribute 'level' (9, 10, 11, or 12)
- Every numerical data point should be contained within an element <Number>, and text descriptions should be contained within an element <Text>
- Use attributes to provide additional details where necessary (e.g., course names, performance categories)
- Ensure proper nesting and indentation for readability

Make up any necessary data not provided under the presumption of a typical high school with a diverse range of academic and extracurricular activities. The data should be plausible and reflect common trends in high school reporting.

```xml
<SchoolPerformanceReport>

    </TotalStudents>
    <AverageGPA>

    </AverageGPA>
    <!-- More summary data -->
  </Summary>
  <!-- More sections -->
</SchoolPerformanceReport>
``` 

Be sure to close all tags appropriately and validate the XML format for syntactic correctness before providing the final output.
